etymology.description: semantic: 氵 “water” + 土 “soil” + phonetic: 日 (OC *njiɡ).
etymology.interpretation: Water and earth together evoke wet soil or sludge, pointing to meanings like mud or blackening. The 日 component contributes the sound (approximating Old Chinese ni-), while the overall composition also pictures muddy, darkened earth.

examples.chinese: 他用草木灰把棉布涅成黑色(他用草木灰把棉布涅成黑色)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng cǎomù huī bǎ miánbù niè chéng hēisè.
examples.english: He used plant ash solution to dye the cotton cloth black.

examples.chinese: 白沙在涅(白沙在涅)，与之俱黑(與之俱黑)。
examples.pinyin: Bái shā zài niè, yǔ zhī jù hēi.
examples.english: White sand, when in black dye, becomes black as well.

examples.chinese: 他在逆境中得到涅槃重生(他在逆境中得到涅槃重生)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài nìjìng zhōng dédào nièpán chóngshēng.
examples.english: He attained a nirvana-like rebirth amid adversity.
